title: ASADA chief McDevitt to leave post in May
text:
ASADA chief executive Ben McDevitt confirms he will leave his role at end of contract in May Posted February 08, 2017 10:45:47 Map: Sydney 2000 
Controversial ASADA chief executive, Ben McDevitt, has confirmed he will leave the agency when his three-year contract ends in May. 
McDevitt who joined Australia's main anti-doping agency in May 2014, was criticised for his handling of the supplements saga at the Essendon and Cronulla clubs. 
He admitted during the case that ASADA was not equipped to deal with an investigation the magnitude of that which rocked the Bombers and Sharks . 
The long-running saga ended with 12 past and present Cronulla players handed backdated 12-month bans for breaching doping regulations. 
The Essendon case went all the way to an appeal by WADA to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which ruled that 34 past and present Bombers players were banned for 12 months , missing the entire 2016 AFL season. 
In a statement on Wednesday, McDevitt confirmed he had advised the Federal minister for sport, Greg Hunt, that he would not be taking up an offer of another three-year term. 
"My experience has convinced me that we face an ongoing threat of doping. It is more sophisticated, more readily available and harder to detect," he said in the statement. 
"There are people willing to push the boundaries with experimental substances and methods which have not been clinically tested or approved for human use. 
"The 'win at all costs' mentality harms athletes, destroys fair play and equitable competition and does irreparable damage to the credibility of sport. ASADA is trying its best to protect clean athletes and their right to compete on a level playing field. 
"During my tenure, I am proud to have overseen a number of positive changes for ASADA and more broadly sport in Australia, including the redevelopment of ASADA's Operating Model and the enhancement of our intelligence and investigative capabilities, enabling us to better target those high-risk sports and individuals."
